awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Project: Diversity of ecosystem services provisioning in coastal socio-ecological systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, and improve research and teaching at the institution. This project at Delaware State University will study ecosystem services for coastal ecosystems. Undergraduate students participate in this project as researchers.
 
Ecosystem services, or the benefits that humans receive from ecosystems, are an important justification for conservation and restoration investments.  However, past studies are conflicted regarding how to assess and when to expect synergies and tradeoffs among services.  Further, few studies have examined these relationships in coastal socioecological systems.  This project aims to quantitatively map a broad suite of services provided by Delaware's coastal ecosystems, including cultural services such as birding use, beach use, park use, boating; provisioning services, such as fisheries; and regulating and supporting services such as flood mitigation and biodiversity preservation.  Spatial models for the total service delivery and diversity of service delivery will be developed based on biodiversity indices and compared at multiple spatial scales.  In addition, service bundles or distinct groups of co-occurring services will be identified and examined across spatial scales and with different land uses using multivariate statistics.  The project will contribute a general framework to evaluate the co-delivery of ecosystem services, and the project will provide an assessment of the delivery of services in highly valued coastal ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This study focused on ecosystem services, or benefits provided by ecosystems to humans, along Delaware's coasts.  The benefits studied in wetlands and coastal waters included different recreational uses, types of food production, and natural functions. Detailed maps of over a dozen of these ecosystem services were completed, estimating how much humans benefited from each service across locations along the coast. Some locations had different benefits than others. Some combinations of benefits occurred together in the same places repeatedly, but other combinations of benefits were rarely observed in the same locations. These findings were summarized into new visualizations of both overall total benefits and the evenness of those benefits across locations. The results allow pinpointing locations with diverse arrays of benefits, which is expected to improve applications in environmental decision-making and management.

 

Several undergraduate students and one graduate student received additional mentorship and training in research skills through this funding. In addition, K-12 educational activities related to the benefits of healthy wetlands and the power of location data were developed. The educational activities were used at outreach events with groups of middle school and high school students in Delaware. Finally, the funding improved research capacity at an HBCU by allowing a faculty member to establish new research directions, and that foundation has continued to impact new projects and students.


Last Modified: 10/14/2024
Modified by: Sigrid Smith
